low.Hemoglobin: Low hemoglobin may indicate anemia, causing fatigue and weakness. Consult your doctor.
low.White Blood Cell Count: Low WBC can affect your immune system. This may indicate infections or bone marrow issues.
low.Red Blood Cell Count: Low RBC may cause fatigue and shortness of breath. Could indicate anemia.
low.Platelet Count: Low platelets may increase bleeding or bruising risk. Your doctor should investigate.
low.Hematocrit: Low hematocrit may indicate anemia or blood loss.
low.MCV: Low MCV suggests small red blood cells, often due to iron deficiency.
low.MCH: Low MCH may indicate iron deficiency anemia.
low.Fasting Blood Sugar: Low blood sugar can cause shakiness, sweating, confusion. Eat something sweet immediately.
low.HbA1c: Low HbA1c is generally good but may indicate frequent low blood sugar episodes.
low.Creatinine: Low creatinine is usually not concerning.
low.eGFR: Low eGFR indicates reduced kidney function. Consult a nephrologist.
low.TSH: Low TSH may indicate overactive thyroid (hyperthyroidism).
low.T3: Low T3 may indicate thyroid dysfunction.
low.T4: Low T4 may indicate underactive thyroid.
low.HDL Cholesterol: Low HDL (good cholesterol) increases heart disease risk. Exercise can help.
low.Sodium: Low sodium can affect fluid balance and neurological function.
low.Potassium: Low potassium can affect heart rhythm and muscle function.
low.Calcium: Low calcium may affect bone health and muscle function.
low.Vitamin D: Low Vitamin D affects bone health and immunity. Sunlight and supplements can help.
low.Vitamin B12: Low B12 may cause fatigue, nerve problems. Supplements may be needed.
low.Iron: Low iron can cause anemia and fatigue. Diet changes or supplements may help.
low.Ferritin: Low ferritin indicates depleted iron stores.
low.Albumin: Low albumin may indicate liver or kidney problems, or malnutrition.
low.Total Protein: Low protein may indicate liver disease or malnutrition.
low.Neutrophils: Low neutrophils may increase infection risk.
low.Lymphocytes: Low lymphocytes may indicate immune system problems.
low.Testosterone: Low testosterone may cause fatigue, low libido. Consult an endocrinologist.
low.default: This value is below normal range. Please consult your doctor for evaluation.

high.Hemoglobin: High hemoglobin may indicate dehydration or a bone marrow condition.
high.White Blood Cell Count: High WBC can occur with infections, inflammation, or stress.
high.Red Blood Cell Count: High RBC may indicate dehydration or lung/heart conditions.
high.Platelet Count: High platelets may increase clotting risk. Further evaluation needed.
high.Fasting Blood Sugar: High fasting sugar may indicate prediabetes or diabetes. Lifestyle changes recommended.
high.Post Prandial Blood Sugar: High PP sugar indicates poor glucose control. Monitor diet and consult doctor.
high.Random Blood Sugar: High random sugar may indicate diabetes. Further testing recommended.
high.HbA1c: High HbA1c indicates poor blood sugar control over past 2-3 months. Lifestyle changes needed.
high.Blood Urea: High urea may indicate kidney problems or dehydration.
high.Blood Urea Nitrogen: High BUN may indicate kidney or liver problems, or dehydration.
high.Creatinine: High creatinine may indicate reduced kidney function. Consult a nephrologist.
high.Uric Acid: High uric acid can cause gout and kidney stones. Reduce purine-rich foods.
high.Total Bilirubin: High bilirubin may indicate liver problems or hemolysis.
high.Direct Bilirubin: High direct bilirubin may indicate bile duct obstruction.
high.SGOT: High SGOT indicates liver cell damage. Avoid alcohol, consult doctor.
high.SGPT: High SGPT indicates liver inflammation. Avoid alcohol and fatty foods.
high.Alkaline Phosphatase: High ALP may indicate liver or bone problems.
high.GGT: High GGT often indicates liver disease or alcohol use.
high.TSH: High TSH may indicate underactive thyroid (hypothyroidism). May need medication.
high.T3: High T3 may indicate overactive thyroid.
high.Total Cholesterol: High total cholesterol increases heart disease risk. Diet and exercise recommended.
high.LDL Cholesterol: High LDL (bad cholesterol) clogs arteries. Reduce saturated fats.
high.Triglycerides: High triglycerides increase heart disease risk. Reduce sugar and alcohol.
high.Sodium: High sodium can increase blood pressure. Reduce salt intake.
high.Potassium: High potassium can affect heart rhythm. May need dietary changes.
high.Calcium: High calcium may indicate parathyroid problems or cancer.
high.Phosphorus: High phosphorus may indicate kidney problems.
high.CRP: High CRP indicates inflammation or infection in the body.
high.ESR: High ESR indicates inflammation. Further tests may be needed.
high.Troponin I: High troponin indicates heart muscle damage. Seek immediate medical attention.
high.Troponin T: High troponin T indicates heart muscle injury. Emergency evaluation needed.
high.CPK-MB: High CPK-MB may indicate heart muscle damage.
high.BNP: High BNP may indicate heart failure or heart strain.
high.D-Dimer: High D-dimer may indicate blood clots. Further evaluation needed.
high.PSA: High PSA needs evaluation for prostate issues.
high.AFP: High AFP may need liver evaluation.
high.CEA: High CEA needs cancer screening evaluation.
high.Urine Protein: Protein in urine may indicate kidney damage.
high.Urine RBC: Blood in urine needs urological evaluation.
high.Urine WBC: Pus cells in urine indicate urinary infection.
high.Homocysteine: High homocysteine increases heart disease risk.
high.Cortisol: High cortisol may indicate stress or Cushing's syndrome.
high.Prolactin: High prolactin may affect fertility. Consult an endocrinologist.
high.default: This value is above normal range. Please consult your doctor for evaluation.

normal.default: This value is within normal range, indicating good health for this test.

categories.hematology: Blood cell tests to check overall blood health
categories.diabetes: Tests to check blood sugar and diabetes control
categories.liver: Tests to check liver health and function
categories.thyroid: Tests to evaluate thyroid gland function
categories.lipid: Tests to check cholesterol and heart disease risk
categories.inflammation: Tests to detect inflammation in body
